rewritten: Like reptiles, birds primarily excrete nitrogenous waste from their bloodstreams as uric acid, rather than urea or ammonia. They lack a urinary bladder and external urethral opening, and uric acid is usually excreted with feces in a semisolid form. However, some birds, such as hummingbirds, can excrete nitrogenous wastes as ammonia, while others, like mammals, excrete creatinine instead of creatine. The material, as well as the output of the intestines, is expelled through the cloaca, a multi-purpose opening that serves as a waste outlet, a mating point, and an egg-laying site. Many bird species regurgitate pellets, and males within certain families, like the Palaeognathae, do not use the cloaca for mating.

Mammalian fur, commonly known as pelage, can exhibit a wide range of colors among different populations, within a population, and on individual animals. It is not uncommon to find light to dark color variations in mammals. While age may sometimes be the factor responsible for these color changes, in other cases, other factors come into play. Selective pressures, such as ecological interactions with other populations or environmental conditions, often contribute to the variations in mammalian coloration. These selective forces typically favor certain colors to enhance an animal's chances of survival. Camouflage is generally considered the primary driving force behind color variation in mammals, although research suggests that factors such as sexual selection, communication, and physiological processes may also influence the development of fur colors. Camouflage is the most prominent mechanism for color variation, as it allows animals to blend in with their surroundings, making it more difficult for predators to spot them.

In Israel, education is highly valued within the national culture, with historical roots dating back to Ancient Israel. Israeli culture views higher education as a key factor in achieving higher mobility and socioeconomic status in Israeli society. This emphasis on education has its roots in the Jewish diaspora, from the Renaissance and Enlightenment Movement to the origins of Zionism in the 1880s. Jewish communities in the Levant were among the first to introduce compulsory education, with the organized community taking responsibility for educating the next generation of Jews. This culture of valuing education is reflected in contemporary Jewish culture's strong emphasis on scholarship, learning, and the promotion of intellectual pursuits. Additionally, Israel's high university educational attainment rate further exemplifies the importance of higher education in Israeli society. The Israeli education system has been praised for its commitment to providing high-quality education to its citizens.

The Daily Northwestern is the main student newspaper, established in 1881 and published during the academic year on weekdays. It is entirely directed by undergraduates and serves the Northwestern community, although it has no ties to the university. Supported by advertisers, it is owned by the Students Publishing Company. North by Northwestern is an online undergraduate magazine, founded in September 2006 by students at the Medill School of Journalism. Published on weekdays, it provides updates on news stories and special events throughout the day and on weekends. North by Northwestern also publishes a quarterly print magazine. Syllabus is the undergraduate yearbook, first published in 1885, and serves as a summary of events at Northwestern. Published by Students Publishing Company and edited by Northwestern students, it is distributed in late May. Northwestern Flipside is an undergraduate satire magazine, founded in 2009.

Following the fall of the Wu and the Wu Hu uprising against the Jin dynasty (265-420), many elite Chinese families collaborated with non-Chinese rulers and military conquerors in the north. Some lost their social privileges and fled to areas south of the Yangtze River. Some of these Chinese refugees from the north may have settled near Hangzhou. For example, the clan of Zhuge Liang (181-234), a chancellor of the state of Shu Han from the Central Plain in north China during the Three Kingdoms period, gathered together in the suburbs of Hangzhou and formed an exclusive, closed village called Zhuge Village, consisting of villagers all with the family name "Zhuge." The village has intentionally isolated itself from surrounding communities for centuries, and it only recently gained public recognition. It suggests that a small number of powerful, elite Chinese refugees from the Central Plain may have taken refuge in this exclusive village.

The '98 season began with a somber note, as legendary broadcaster Harry Caray passed away. The Cubs had to fill the void left by the retirement of Sandberg and the trade of Dunston. To help protect Sammy Sosa in the lineup, they signed Henry Rodríguez, known as "H-Rod," who slugged 31 round-trippers in his first season with the team. Kevin Tapani led the club with a career-high 19 wins, and Rod Beck anchored a strong bullpen. Mark Grace had one of his best seasons. The Cubs were in the spotlight in 1998, with Sosa and rookie flamethrower Kerry Wood as their biggest headliners. Wood's signature performance was one-hitting the Houston Astros, tying the major league record of 20 strikeouts in nine innings. His impressive strikeout numbers earned him the nickname "Kid K," and ultimately the 1998 NL Rookie of the Year award. Sosa caught fire in June, hitting a major league record 20 home runs in the month.

In contemporary society, adolescents experience various risks as their sexual identity evolves. Although some risks, such as emotional distress from fear of abuse or exploitation, and sexually transmitted infections/diseases (STIs/STDs), including HIV/AIDS, are not exclusive to adolescence, other risks like teenage pregnancy through contraceptive failure are often viewed as social issues in many Western societies. One in four sexually active teenagers contracts an STI. In the United States, adolescents tend to engage in non-intercourse sexual activities, mistakenly believing that this reduces the risk of STIs. Clinicians report an increasing number of cases of herpes and human papillomavirus (HPV), which can cause genital warts, and it is estimated that 15% of adults in the country have HPV.

Throughout the history of the South Slavs, various vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) have developed and evolved independently in different regions and ethnicities. Before the 19th century, these languages were collectively referred to as "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". The term "Serbo-Croatian" was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, and later popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades. It was officially referred to as "Serbo-Croat", "Croato-Serbian", "Serbian and Croatian", "Croatian and Serbian", "Serbian or Croatian", "Croatian or Serbian", and "Serbian or Croatian" in different variations. However, unofficially, Serbs and Croats typically referred to the language as "Serbian" or "Croatian" without implying any distinction between the two. In independent Bosnia and Herzegovina, "Bosnian", "Croatian", and "Serbian" were considered as three names for a single language.

Adolescence is a stage of life characterized by identity development, a process through which individuals explore their identities and personalities. This typically begins in the adolescent years and involves trying on different behaviors, appearances, and identities to discover who they are. However, maintaining an identity in this stage can be challenging due to various factors such as family life, environment, and social status. While it is often referred to as identity development, empirical studies suggest that the process can be more accurately described as identity development, confirming that it involves both changes in content and structure.

The expansive Seleucid Empire, like Egypt, was primarily controlled by a Greco-Macedonian political elite. The dominant Greek population in the cities, which included newly founded colonies such as Antioch, the other cities of the Syrian tetrapolis, Seleucia, and Dura-Europos on the Euphrates, retained traditional Greek city-state institutions such as assemblies, councils, and elected magistrates. However, these institutions were merely a facade, as they were always under the control of the royal Seleucid officials. In addition to these cities, there were numerous Seleucid garrisons, military colonies, and Greek villages established throughout the empire to ensure the establishment of their rule. This population of 'Greco-Macedonians' was essential to the Seleucid Empire's political and military power.

The implications are numerous as various research traditions are currently heavily using the lens of identity to examine various phenomena. One implication of identity and identity construction can be seen in occupational settings. This becomes increasingly challenging in stigmatized jobs or "dirty work" (Hughes, 1951). Tracy and Trethewey (2005) stated that individuals tend to gravitate towards or avoid certain jobs to a certain extent based on how much they validate a "preferred organizational self" (Tracy & Tretheway, 2005, p. 169). Some jobs carry different stigmas or praises. In her analysis, Tracy uses the example of correctional officers trying to shake off the stigma of being "glorified maids" (Tracy & Tretheway, 2005). The process by which people arrive at justifications for and values for various occupational choices is also examined. Among these factors are workplace satisfaction and overall quality of life (Tracy & Scott, 2006, p. 33). Individuals in these types of jobs may experience various emotions and attitudes towards their work.

Emotions play a significant role in social interactions and relationships, and as a result, are intricately connected to basic physiology, especially the stress systems. This connection is crucial because emotions are linked to the anti-stress complex, which involves an oxytocin-attachment system that plays a critical role in bonding. Emotional traits, such as temperaments, can affect social connectedness and fitness in complex social systems, as observed in various species and taxa. These characteristics are passed down through generations due to the influence of genes, which are encoded in DNA sequences and serve as a blueprint for assembling proteins that make up cells.

Stanley Schachter's theory was based on the earlier work of a Spanish physician, Gregorio Marañón, who injected patients with epinephrine and then asked them how they felt. Surprisingly, Marañón discovered that most of these patients felt something, but in the absence of a stimulus that would evoke an emotion, the patients were unable to interpret their physiological arousal as an emotional experience. Schachter agreed that physiological reactions play a significant role in emotions. He suggested that these reactions contribute to emotional experience by facilitating a focused cognitive appraisal of a particular, emotionally arousing event, and that this appraisal is what defines the subjective emotional experience. Consequently, emotions are the result of a two-stage process: general physiological arousal and the subsequent experience of the emotion. For instance, the physiological arousal of a pounding heart can occur in response to an emotionally evocative stimulus, such as a bear in the kitchen.

The political unrest continued. John decided to form an alliance with King Philip II of France, who had just returned from the crusade. John wanted to acquire Normandy, Anjou, and other lands in France held by Richard in exchange for joining forces with Philip. However, John's mother persuaded him not to pursue an alliance. Longchamp, who had left England after Walter's intervention, returned and argued that he had been wrongly removed as justiciar. John intervened and agreed to support Longchamp's claims in return for promises of support from the royal administration, including a reaffirmation of his position as the heir to the throne. When Richard still did not return from the crusade, John began to claim that his brother was dead or otherwise permanently lost. In fact, Richard had been captured by the Duke of Austria and handed over to Emperor Henry VI, who held him for ransom. John took advantage of this situation and made plans to take control of the English throne.

During the Early Modern period, universities continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages, covering subjects such as natural philosophy, logic, medicine, theology, mathematics, astronomy, astrology, law, and grammar and rhetoric. Aristotle was widely studied, and medicine also relied on the works of Galen and Arabic scholarship. The humanist movement played a significant role in transforming this state-of-affairs. When humanist professors joined the faculty, they introduced the studia humanitatis, focusing on students' abilities to communicate effectively, translate and interpret classical texts, and lead honorable lives. The humanist approach to learning and expertise in ancient texts influenced other scholars within the university, promoting the ultimate importance of these texts. Professors of medicine, such as Niccolò Leoniceno, Thomas Linacre, and William Cop, were often taught from a humanist perspective.

The Democratic Party candidates were consistently elected to local office, which strengthened the city's ties to the South and its dominant party. In 1861, Mayor Fernando Wood proposed declaring independence from Albany and the United States after the South seceded, but his proposal was not implemented. The American Civil War (1861-1865) military conscription laws, which spared wealthier men who could pay a $300 (equivalent to $5,766 in 2016) commutation fee, led to the Draft Riots of 1863, which involved ethnic Irish working class. The situation in the city deteriorated into attacks on New York's elite, followed by attacks on black New Yorkers and their property, after a decade-long competition between Irish immigrants and blacks for work. During the Draft Riots, rioters burned the Colored Orphan Asylum to the ground, but more than 200 children escaped harm due to the efforts of the institution's staff.

But during the mid-18th century, during the French Enlightenment, a more ideological usage of the term emerged. In 1765, an anonymous author in a French Enlightenment periodical discussed "The general love of humanity... a virtue previously unrecognized among us, and which we will courageously call 'humanism', as the time has come to create a word for such a beautiful and necessary idea." During the latter half of the 18th and early 19th centuries, many grassroots "philanthropic" and benevolent societies emerged dedicated to human betterment and the spread of knowledge, with both Christian and non-Christian affiliations. Following the French Revolution, the notion that human virtue could be developed solely through human reason, independent of traditional religious institutions, was attributed by opponents of the Revolution to Enlightenment philosophers such as Rousseau. This viewpoint was met with strong opposition.

The outcome was a series of creative yet unpopular financial actions. During his seventeen-year reign, King John imposed scutage payments eleven times, compared to eleven times in total throughout the rule of the three preceding monarchs. In numerous instances, these taxes were imposed even when there were no actual military campaigns. This went against the original concept of scutage as an alternative to actual military service. John maximized his ability to demand relief payments when estates and castles were inherited, sometimes charging exorbitant sums beyond barons' financial capabilities. Building on the successful sale of sheriff appointments in 1194, John initiated a new round of appointments, with the new incumbents recovering their investments through increased fines and penalties, particularly in the forests. Another innovation of Richard's, the increased charges levied on widows who wished to remain single, was expanded under John. John continued to sell charters for new towns, including

During the Enlightenment, various novel concepts concerning religion emerged, including Deism and discussions of atheism. Deism, as described by Thomas Paine, involves a simple belief in God as the Creator, without reference to the Bible or any other supernatural sources. Instead, a Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide their beliefs, a perspective that was widely appreciated by many thinkers of the time.

Atheism was a topic of frequent debate, although there were few vocal proponents. Wilson and Reill emphasize that, "in fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they criticized Christianity, were true atheists. Instead, they were critics of orthodox beliefs, leaning towards skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some adhered to Pierre Bayle's position, arguing that atheists could still maintain a strong moral compass. However, many others, such as Voltaire, held that the absence of a belief in a God who punishes evil undermined the moral order of society. That is, since atheists did not submit to any Supreme Authority, no law, and had no fear of any repercussions, the moral fabric of society was weakened.

Sleep does not affect memory acquisition or recall when a person is awake. This indicates that sleep plays a significant role in memory consolidation. During sleep, the brain strengthens neural connections, which enhances the brain's ability to stabilize and retain memories. Numerous studies have shown that sleep improves memory retention by promoting active consolidation of memories. System consolidation occurs during slow-wave sleep (SWS), during which memories are reactivated, but not all memories are enhanced. Additionally, qualitative changes are made to the memories when they are transferred to the long-term store during sleep. When you sleep, the hippocampus replays the events of the day for the neocortex, which then reviews and processes the memories, moving them into long-term memory. If you don't get enough sleep, it can be more difficult to learn, as these neural connections are not as strong, leading to lower memory retention.

Despite the common belief that memory functions as a recording device, this is not the case. The molecular processes that underlie memory formation and maintenance are highly dynamic and encompass multiple stages that span over time windows ranging from mere seconds to an entire lifetime. In fact, research has shown that our memories are not fixed but rather are constructed. This process occurs during both memory encoding and recall. For example, consider a study conducted by Elizabeth Loftus and John Palmer in 1974, in which participants were asked to watch a traffic accident video and then provide information about it. Those who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?" reported higher speeds than those who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they hit each other?" Additionally, those participants who were asked about broken glass a week later were twice as likely to report having seen it, even though it was not actually present in the video.

During the second millennium BC, the region of modern Zhejiang existed outside the major cultural sphere of influence of the Shang civilization. Instead, this area was inhabited by various tribal groups collectively referred to as the Hundred Yue, including the Dongyue and the Ouyue. The kingdom of Yue first emerged in historical records during the Spring and Autumn Period. According to these records, the kingdom of Yue was located in the northern part of Zhejiang. Shiji asserts that the leaders of the kingdom of Yue were descendants of the Shang founder, Yu the Great. Evidence suggests that the culture and history of both the kingdom of Yue and the Baiyue were distinct from those of other kingdoms in north and central China. These cultures and histories were meticulously recorded in historical records during the Spring and Autumn Period and the Qin dynasty.

Protestantism also extended from German territories to France, where the Protestant believers were referred to as Huguenots. Calvin remained interested in French religious affairs from his base in Geneva, regularly training pastors to lead congregations there. Despite the heavy persecution, the Reformed tradition made steady progress throughout the nation, appealing to people who were alienated by the stubbornness and complacency of the Catholic establishment. French Protestantism acquired a distinctly political character, becoming more evident with the conversions of nobles in the 1550s. This set the stage for a series of conflicts, known as the French Wars of Religion. The civil wars gained momentum with the unexpected death of Henry II of France in 1559. Atrocity and outrage became defining characteristics of the time, reaching their peak during the St. Bartholomew's Day massacre on August 1572, when the Roman Catholic party massacred between 30,000 and 100,000 Huguenots across France.

Compared to other team sports, the National Football League (NFL) preseason has a well-structured format. Each team competes in four pre-season exhibition games annually, two at home and two away, with the exception of two teams who partake in an additional game, known as the Pro Football Hall of Fame Game. These exhibition matches generally take place in August and serve the purpose of assisting coaches in reducing the offseason roster size from 90 players to the 53 players permitted during the regular season. While the scheduling formula for preseason games is more flexible compared to the regular season, there are still certain limitations and traditions that dictate the selection of preseason opponents. Teams are also restricted in terms of the days and times when they can play these games. Similar to practices observed in baseball and hockey, split-squad matches are sometimes employed by NFL teams, where a single squad is divided to play two games on the same day.

During the early and mid-1980s, Libya faced economic difficulties, with their annual oil revenue decreasing from $21 billion in 1982 to $5.4 billion in 1986. In response, the government focused on irrigation projects, starting construction on the Great Man-Made River in 1983, designed to be completed by the end of the decade, but remained incomplete by the start of the 21st century. Military spending increased, while other administrative budgets were reduced. Libya had long supported the FROLINAT militia in Chad, which led to their re-invasion of Chad in December 1980, and their continued involvement in the civil war. The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) rejected Gaddafi's suggestion of a political merger, and called for a Libyan withdrawal. This withdrawal occurred in November 1981, but the civil war continued, leading Libya to send troops back into Chad and clashing with French forces supporting southern Chadian forces.

The event took place in Seoul, the site of the 1988 Summer Olympics, on April 27. Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun boycotted the event to protest against the Chinese government's crackdown in Tibet. More than 8,000 riot police were deployed to protect the 24-kilometer route, which began at the Olympic Park, which was constructed when Seoul hosted the 1988 Summer Games. On the day of the torch relay in Seoul, Chinese students clashed with protesters, throwing rocks, bottles, and punches. A North Korean defector whose brother defected to China but was captured and executed by the DPRK, attempted to set himself on fire in protest of China's treatment of North Korean refugees. He poured gasoline on himself but police quickly surrounded him and carried him away. Two other demonstrators tried to stop the torch but failed. Fighting broke out near the beginning of the relay between a group of 500 Chinese supporters and approximately the same number of protesters.

The conceptions of separation of powers, held by Jefferson and James Madison, have long been the subject of debate. Jefferson, as President, did not issue any Proclamations of Thanksgiving sent to him by Congress, but did issue a Thanksgiving and Prayer proclamation as Governor of Virginia. On the other hand, Madison issued four religious proclamations as President, but vetoed two bills on the grounds that they violated the first amendment. Both Jefferson and Madison also attended religious services at the Capitol. In his writings before the ratification of the Constitution, Madison argued, "If Religion be exempt from the authority of the Society at large, still less can it be subject to that of the Legislative Body." After retiring from the presidency, Madison wrote about "total separation of the church from the state." He emphasized the strong separation between religion and government in the Constitution of the United States and described the practical distinction between religion and civil government.

The works of Virgil have left a significant impact on Latin poetry, changing the landscape of the genre almost immediately upon their release. The Eclogues, Georgics, and especially the Aeneid became essential texts in school curricula, familiarized to all educated Romans. Poets following in Virgil's footsteps often reference his works to generate meaning in their own poems. Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1, and his summary of Aeneas' story in Book 14 of Metamorphoses, known as the "mini-Aeneid," has been considered a significant example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile, is considered an anti-Virgilian work, deviating from Virgil's focus on divine mechanisms and historical events. Flavian poet Statius, in his 12-book epic Thebaid, closely engages with Virgil's poetry, advising his work to "follow afar and ever venerate the footsteps" of the divine Aeneid. In Silius Italicus, Virgil's influence is evident as well.

Terry Eastland, the author of "Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice," claims that most arguments for affirmative action fall into two categories: remedying past discrimination and promoting diversity. Eastland believes that the founding fathers of affirmative action did not anticipate how the benefits of affirmative action would be enjoyed by those who did not need it, primarily middle-class minorities. Additionally, she argues that affirmative action carries a stigma that can create feelings of self-doubt and entitlement in minorities. Eastland believes that affirmative action is a high-risk strategy that sometimes fails to deliver benefits, and that without it, individuals would have more freedom to compete with one another. Libertarian economist Thomas Sowell, in his book "Affirmative Action Around the World: An Empirical Study," has identified negative consequences of affirmative action. Sowell claims that affirmative action policies encourage non-preferred groups to claim membership in preferred groups (i.e., primary beneficiaries of affirmative action) in order to enjoy the benefits.

During this era, the United States' largest military engagement was the War of 1812, which took place as Britain was fighting against France in a major war. In an attempt to block American shipments to France, Britain adopted a policy of trade restrictions and impressed American sailors into the Royal Navy, despite protests. To further hinder American expansion, Britain also supported an Indian uprising in the American Midwest. Ultimately, the United States declared war on the United Kingdom in 1812, marking the first time the nation had officially declared war. However, the U.S. was not confident in its ability to defeat the Royal Navy and instead chose to invade British Canada, hoping to use captured territory as leverage in negotiations. While the invasion of Canada was a failure, the United States had some success in concurrent wars against Native Americans, such as Tecumseh's War and the Creek War. Following Napoleon's defeat in 1814, Britain sent large veteran armies to invade the United States, but the conflict was ultimately resolved through the Treaty of Ghent, which ended the war in 1815.

Regarding the outer regions, the Qing maintained imperial control, with the emperor serving as the Mongol khan, patron of Tibetan Buddhism, and protector of Muslims. However, Qing policy changed following the establishment of Xinjiang province in 1884. During The Great Game era, taking advantage of the Dungan uprising in northwest China, Yaqub Beg invaded Xinjiang from Central Asia with support from the British Empire, and declared himself the ruler of the kingdom of Kashgaria. The Qing court dispatched forces to defeat Yaqub Beg and reconquered Xinjiang. Subsequently, the political system of China proper was formally implemented in Xinjiang. The Kumul Khanate, which became a vassal of the Qing empire after helping to defeat the Zunghars in 1757, maintained its status when Xinjiang became a province up until 1930. Brigham Young University, or BYU, boasts 21 NCAA varsity teams. Of these, 19 teams have primarily competed in the Mountain West Conference since its inception in 1999 until the school left in 2011. Prior to this time, BYU teams participated in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are known as the "Cougars," and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Due to the fact that many of its players serve full-time missions for two years (men at 18, women at 19), BYU athletes tend to be older on average compared to those from other schools. The NCAA permits students to serve missions for two years without deducting this time from their eligibility period. Although this has sparked minor controversy, it is generally agreed that it does not provide the school with any significant advantage, as players receive no athletic or physical training during their missions. BYU has also garnered attention from sports networks for its refusal to play games on certain days, such as Sundays.

John considered the interdict as a direct challenge to his authority. He responded by attempting to hold Innocent personally accountable and to create division between the English clergy who might support him and those who allied themselves with the Roman authorities. John seized the lands of clergy who refused to conduct services or those linked to Innocent himself; he arrested the concubines of some clerics during this time, only releasing them after fines were paid. He also seized the lands of English church members who had fled the country, and he promised protection to clergy who remained loyal to him. In many cases, individual institutions were able to negotiate terms for managing their own properties and keeping the produce of their estates. By 1209, the situation had yet to be resolved, and Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not accept Langton's appointment. When this threat failed, Innocent issued the excommunication.

In Mainland China, Japanese divisions 3rd, 6th, and 40th gathered at Yueyang and advanced south in three columns, crossing the Xinqiang River and attempting to cross the Miluo River to reach Changsha. In January 1942, Chinese forces gained a victory at Changsha, marking the first Allied success against Japan. Following the Doolittle Raid, the Japanese army executed a sweeping campaign through Zhejiang and Jiangxi, known as the Zhejiang-Jiangxi Campaign, targeting American airmen and Chinese allies while destroying air bases. This operation began on May 15 with 40 infantry battalions and 15-16 artillery battalions but was repelled by Chinese forces by September, leaving behind a path of destruction.

A tech media website, CNET, has awarded the new Super Slim PlayStation 3 with a rating of 4 out of 5 stars, stating that it is "Excellent". The Super Slim console packs a powerful gaming machine into a smaller package, while maintaining its gaming library and streaming services. However, the reviewer criticized the design as being cheap, pointing out that the disc loader can be frustrating to use. They also mentioned that the absence of an autoloading disc tray makes the console feel cheap compared to the previous models. Additionally, the cheapest Super Slim model is still more expensive than the cheapest Slim model, and the upgraded hard drive can be easily replaced in a Slim model. Overall, the reviewer feels that the smaller size and bigger hard drive should not be considered an upgrade due to the absence of key features.

In July 1645, Dorgon issued a controversial edict, which required adult Han Chinese men to shave the front of their heads and wear the queue hairstyle, a Manchu tradition. Those who did not comply faced death. This edict was popularized as, "To keep the hair, you lose the head; To keep your head, you cut the hair." The Manchus saw this policy as a test of loyalty, while the Han Chinese perceived it as a humiliating reminder of Qing authority and a challenge to their traditional Confucian values, as per the Classic of Filial Piety (Xiaojing), which states that "a person's body and hair, being gifts from one's parents, are not to be damaged." During the Ming dynasty, adult men did not cut their hair but wore it in long strands.

Boundaries can be viewed as inclusive or exclusive, depending on how they are perceived by others. For example, an exclusive boundary is established when a person sets rules for the behavior of others. In contrast, an inclusive boundary is created through the use of a marker that others are comfortable associating with. However, this inclusive boundary may also impose restrictions on the individuals it encompasses by limiting their interaction with other boundaries. For instance, a newcomer who speaks a particular language in a room full of people speaking various languages may be understood by some but not others. Those who do not understand the language may perceive it as an exclusive boundary, indicating that they are excluded from the newcomer's group.

Various manufacturers introduced flexible, or so-called "unbreakable," records made of unusual materials during the 78 rpm era. In the UK, Nicole records, made of celluloid or a similar substance coated onto a cardboard core disc, were produced for a few years beginning in 1904, but they suffered from an exceptionally high level of surface noise. In the United States, Columbia Records introduced flexible, fiber-cored "Marconi Velvet Tone Record" pressings in 1907, but the advantages and longevity of their relatively noiseless surfaces depended on the scrupulous use of special gold-plated Marconi Needles, and the product was not a success. Thin, flexible plastic records such as the German Phonycord and the British Filmophone and Goodson records appeared around 1930 but also did not last long. The contemporary French Pathé Cellodiscs, made of a very thin black plastic, which uncannily resembles the original material, were introduced during this time.

In 1919, following the Treaty of Versailles, Strasbourg was restituted to France in accordance with U.S. President Woodrow Wilson's "Fourteen Points," without a referendum. The date of the transfer was set retroactively to Armistice Day. It is uncertain whether a referendum in Strasbourg would have favored France, as the political parties seeking an autonomous Alsace or a connection to France only accounted for a small proportion of votes in the last Reichstag and local elections. The Alsatian autonomists who were pro-French had won many votes in the more rural parts of the region and other towns since the annexation of the region by Germany in 1871. The movement began with the first election for the Reichstag; those elected were called "les députés protestataires," and until the fall of Bismarck in 1890, they were the only deputies elected by the Alsatians to the German parliament.

As the Western European kingdoms were established, the Eastern Roman Empire remained strong and experienced an economic revival that lasted until the early 7th century. There were fewer invasions in the eastern part of the empire, most of them occurring in the Balkans. A peace with Persia, a long-time enemy of Rome, lasted throughout much of the 5th century. The Eastern Empire featured closer ties between the political state and the Christian Church, with religious matters becoming increasingly important in eastern politics compared to Western Europe. Legal developments included the codification of Roman law, with the first effort, the Theodosian Code, completed in 438. Under Emperor Justinian (r. 527–565), another compilation took place, the Corpus Juris Civilis. Justinian also oversaw the construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople and the reconquest of North Africa from the Vandals and Italy from the Ostrogoths, under Belisarius (d. 565). The conquest of Italy was not complete, as a deadly outbreak of plague in 542 led Justinian's reign to focus on defensive measures.

When Nintendo introduced its NES console in the United States, the design was purposely different from those of other gaming systems. The company aimed to distinguish its product from competitors and to avoid the generally negative image that gaming consoles had acquired following the video game crash in 1983. One outcome of this strategy was to disguise the cartridge slot design as a front-loading zero insertion force (ZIF) cartridge socket, which was designed to resemble the front-loading mechanism of a VCR. The newly designed connector worked well when both the connector and the cartridges were clean, and the pins on the connector were new. However, the ZIF connector was not truly zero insertion force. When users inserted the cartridge into the NES, the force of pressing the cartridge down and into place bent the contact pins slightly, as well as pressing the cartridge's ROM board back into the cartridge itself. Frequent insertion and removal of cartridges caused the pins to wear out over the years and the ZIF connector eventually malfunctioned.

Protestants played a key role in advocating for religious freedom. The issue of freedom of conscience held a high priority on theological, philosophical, and political agendas due to the refusal of Martin Luther to recant his beliefs at the Diet of the Holy Roman Empire in Worms (1521). Luther believed that faith was a free work of the Holy Spirit and thus could not be forced upon a person. Persecuted groups such as the Anabaptists and Huguenots demanded freedom of conscience, and they practiced separation of church and state. In the early 17th century, Baptist leaders like John Smyth and Thomas Helwys published tracts in defense of religious freedom. Their ideas influenced the stances of figures like John Milton and John Locke on tolerance. Under the leadership of Baptist Roger Williams, Congregationalist Thomas Hooker, and Quaker William Penn, respectively, Rhode Island, Connecticut, and Pennsylvania combined democratic constitutions with freedom of religion. These colonies became safe havens for persecuted religious minorities, including Jews. The United States Declaration of Independence, the United States Constitution, and the American Bill of Rights all recognize the importance of religious freedom and the right to practice one's faith.

Birds possess a highly efficient method of supplying oxygen to their blood, with a tenfold greater surface area for gas exchange than mammals. As a result, birds have more blood in their capillaries for every unit of lung volume compared to mammals. The arteries are made up of thick, elastic muscles to withstand the pressure of ventricular constriction and become more rigid as they move away from the heart. Blood flows through the arteries, which undergo vasoconstriction, and enters arterioles, which function as a transportation system to distribute oxygen and nutrients to all parts of the body. As the arterioles move away from the heart and into individual organs and tissues, they further divide to increase surface area and slow blood flow. The blood then moves into capillaries, where gas exchange can take place. Capillaries are organized into capillary beds in tissues, facilitating efficient gas exchange and nutrient delivery.

The men's basketball team has achieved 1,600+ wins, making it one of the 12 schools with such a record. They have participated in 28 NCAA tournaments. Former player Austin Carr holds the tournament's record for scoring the most points, with 61, in a single game. Although they have not won the NCAA Tournament, they were named national champions by the Helms Athletic Foundation twice. The team has managed to upset number one ranked teams multiple times, most notably ending UCLA's record 88-game winning streak in 1974. They have beaten eight additional number-one teams, making their total of nine wins the second-highest in history against the top team, with 10 wins overall. The team plays in the newly renovated Purcell Pavilion, which reopened for the 2009-10 season. They are coached by Mike Brey, who has been coaching since the 2014-15 season.

One hundred years after the fall of Constantinople in 1453, Pierre Belon described in his work "Observations" published in 1553 that the mixture of pitch and bitumen, known as pissasphalto, was used in Dubrovnik for tarring of ships, and was later exported to a marketplace in Venice. An 1838 edition of Mechanics Magazine cites an early use of asphalt in France. A pamphlet dated 1621 by "a certain Monsieur d'Eyrinys" states that asphaltum was discovered in large quantities in the vicinity of Neufchatel, and proposed to use it in a variety of ways, mainly in the construction of air-proof granaries, and in protecting water-courses in the city of Paris from the intrusion of dirt and filth.

Marshall Field & Company was founded in 1852. It was the leading department store on State Street, the main shopping street in the Midwest, attracting upscale customers who traveled by train from the surrounding region. They also patronized nearby hotels. The company eventually grew to become a major chain before being renamed Macy's on September 9, 2006. Marshall Field's was known for its exceptional customer service, as well as its iconic Frango mints, which were first introduced by Frederick & Nelson Department Store. The store also had many firsts, such as the first European buying office and the first bridal registry. Additionally, Marshall Field's was the first to offer a personal shopping service, which was provided for free in all its stores until the end of the chain.

Some streetcars used a third-rail to collect current. The third rail was at street level. The tram picked up the current through a plow accessed through a narrow slot in the road. In the United States, many former streetcar systems in Washington, D.C. (discontinued in 1962) and Manhattan operated in this way to avoid the unsightly wires and poles associated with electric traction. Similar to London's abandoned Kingsway Tramway Subway, the evidence of this mode of running can still be seen on the track down the slope on the northern access, and on P and Q Streets west of Wisconsin Avenue in the Georgetown neighborhood.

According to the 2010 Census, Asian Americans in New York City numbered more than one million, surpassing the combined totals of San Francisco and Los Angeles. As the most populous U.S. city, New York contains the highest total Asian population. The borough of Queens is home to the largest Asian American population in the state, as well as the largest Andean (Colombian, Ecuadorian, Peruvian, and Bolivian) populations in the United States. It also boasts the highest degree of ethnic diversity among urban areas worldwide.

The Chinese population is the fastest-growing nationality in New York State, and multiple satellite Chinatowns have emerged in Brooklyn and around Flushing, Queens. These traditional urban enclaves are thriving while also rapidly expanding into suburban Nassau County on Long Island. As a result, New York City and the surrounding area have become the top destinations for new Chinese immigrants, with large-scale Chinese immigration continuing into the city and surrounding areas. In 2012, 6.3% of New York City's population was Chinese.

In their 2003 paper, "Human Genetic Diversity and the Nonexistence of Biological Races", Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles provide a detailed critique of the application of FST to human populations. They argue that the commonly cited figure of 85% is misleading as it suggests that all human populations contain on average 85% of all genetic diversity. However, they claim that this figure does not accurately reflect human population history, as it treats all human groups as independent from one another. To better understand the relationships between human groups, it is important to recognize that some groups are the ancestors of others, making them paraphyletic, meaning they are derived from a common ancestor. For example, under the recent African origin theory, the human population in Africa is paraphyletic to all other human groups, as it represents the ancestral group from which all non-African populations derive. However, this figure of 85% is overly simplified and does not consider the complex relationships between human populations.

In recent years, Libya's economy has undergone significant changes with an increased focus on privatization. While the government has rejected the idea of nationalized industries advocated in The Green Book, they have described their approach as "people's socialism" rather than capitalism. This shift in policy has been welcomed by the government and has led to widespread privatization, with the oil industry being sold to private corporations in 2003 and $40 billion of direct foreign investment by 2004. However, some sectors of the population have expressed opposition to these changes through public demonstrations. Despite this, the pace of change has not been completely halted, and in 2010, plans were announced to further privatize half of the Libyan economy over the next decade. While these changes have occurred, there has not been an accompanying political liberalization, with the government retaining control. In 2010, the government also delegated further powers to municipal councils.

The initial military exercises began in September 1806. A notable letter to Marshal Soult described the plan for the campaign, in which Napoleon outlined the main characteristics of Napoleonic warfare and introduced the phrase "square battalion" (le bataillon-carré). According to this system, the various divisions of the Grande Armée would march together in close proximity to provide timely support to each other. If one division was attacked, the others could quickly mobilize and come to its aid. Napoleon led 180,000 troops to invade Prussia, rapidly advancing to the right bank of the River Saale. As in previous campaigns, he sought to eliminate one opponent before the arrival of reinforcements could tip the balance of the war. Following the discovery of the Prussian army's position, the French army pivoted towards the west and crossed the Saale with overwhelming force. The twin battles of Jena and Auerstedt took place on October 14th, and the French army decisively won the battles.

Regarding the timing of Germany's rapprochement, many historians believe that the dismissal of Maxim Litvinov, who was Jewish and unpopular with Nazi Germany, eliminated a barrier to negotiations. Stalin immediately ordered Molotov to "purge the ministry of Jews." Litvinov's previous attempts to form an anti-fascist coalition, association with the doctrine of collective security with France and Britain, and pro-Western stance, indicated that his dismissal signaled a possible Soviet rapprochement with Germany. Similarly, Molotov's appointment sent a signal to Germany that the USSR was open to negotiations. The dismissal also indicated to France and Britain that a potential negotiation option with Germany existed. One British official wrote that Litvinov's disappearance meant the loss of an admirable technician, while Molotov's approach was seen as "more truly Bolshevik than diplomatic or cosmopolitan." Critics labeled Gaddafi as despotic, cruel, arrogant, vain, and foolish. Western governments and media portrayed him as a vicious ruler of an oppressed people. During the Reagan administration, the United States considered him Public Enemy No. 1 and Reagan famously called him the "mad dog of the Middle East." According to critics, the Libyan people lived in a climate of fear under Gaddafi's rule, due to his government's extensive surveillance of civilians. Gaddafi's Libya was typically described as a police state by western commentators. Opponents were critical of Libya's human rights abuses, with organizations such as Human Rights Watch (HRW) and others reporting that hundreds of arrested political opponents often did not receive fair trials and were sometimes subjected to torture or extrajudicial executions, most notably in the Abu Salim prison, including an alleged massacre on 29 June 1996, according to HRW estimates.

A true predator is known for capturing and consuming other living beings. Unlike other types of predators, which cause harm to their prey in some way, true predators kill them. Predators can either actively hunt for prey or wait and ambush their prey, as in the case of ambush predators. Some predators may kill large prey and dismember or chew it before eating it, such as jaguars or humans. Others may swallow their smaller prey whole, like bottlenose dolphins eating fish or snakes, ducks, or storks swallowing frogs. Some predators, like domestic cats and dogs, may do either depending on the situation; they would consume a large insect whole but dismember a rabbit. Some predation involves venom that subdues prey before the predator consumes it, as in the case of venomous snakes.

The Israelites experienced political independence twice in ancient history, first during the times of the Biblical judges and then in the United Monarchy. Following the fall of the United Monarchy, the land was divided into Israel and Judah. The term "Jew" originated from the Roman "Judean" and referred to someone from the southern kingdom of Judah. The shift in the ethnonym from "Israelites" to "Jews" (referring to residents of Judah) was not found in the Torah, but is explicitly mentioned in the Book of Esther, which was written in the 4th century BCE and is part of the Jewish Tanakh.

In 587 BC, Nebuchadnezzar II, the King of the Neo-Babylonian Empire, besieged Jerusalem, destroyed the First Temple, and deported the most prominent citizens of Judah. In 586 BC, Judah ceased to be an independent kingdom, and its remaining citizens were left stateless. The Babylonian exile ended in 539 BCE when the Achaemenid Empire conquered Babylon and Cyrus the Great allowed Jewish exiles to return to Judah and rebuild their temple.

Van Praag states that the Ming court formed diplomatic missions with Tibet to secure urgently needed horses. Wang and Nyima argue that these missions were not diplomatic in nature, claiming that Tibetan regions were under Ming control due to Tibetan leaders being appointed as Ming officials. The collection of horses from Tibet was viewed as a mandatory "corvée" tax, and therefore Tibetans were engaged in domestic affairs rather than foreign diplomacy. Sperling writes that the Ming simultaneously purchased horses in the Kham region while battling Tibetan tribes in Amdo and receiving Tibetan embassies in Nanjing. He also posits that the Tibetan lamas' embassies to the Ming court primarily aimed to facilitate commercial transactions between the lamas' large entourage and Ming Chinese merchants and officials. Kolmaš notes that while the Ming maintained a hands-off approach to Tibet and limited the number of Tibetan retinues, the Tibetans sought to maintain a tributary relationship with the Ming due to imperial patronage.

The Guangxu Emperor passed away on November 14, 1908, and the following day, November 15, Cixi also passed away. Rumors circulated that she, or possibly Yuan Shikai, had ordered trusted eunuchs to poison the Guangxu Emperor. An autopsy conducted decades later confirmed the presence of lethal levels of arsenic in the Emperor's body. Puyi, the first-born son of Prince Chun and the nephew of the childless Guangxu Emperor, was appointed his successor at a young age of two, leaving Zaifeng to hold the regency. As a result, General Yuan Shikai was dismissed from his previous positions of power. In April 1911, Zaifeng established a cabinet comprised of two vice-premiers, but this administration was also known by contemporaries as "The Royal Cabinet" due to the presence of five members of the royal family among the thirteen cabinet members.

The plumage of birds is regularly lost and replaced, with the standard plumage of a bird that has lost its feathers after breeding being known as the "non-breeding" plumage, or in the Humphrey-Parkes terminology, "basic" plumage. Breeding plumages or variations of the basic plumage are known under the Humphrey-Parkes system as "alternate" plumages. The process of losing and regrowing feathers, or "moult," occurs annually in most species, although some may have two moults per year, and large birds of prey may only moult once every few years. The pattern of moult varies across species. In passerines, for example, the flight feathers are replaced one at a time, starting with the innermost primary feather. As the fifth or sixth primary feather is replaced, the outermost tertiaries begin to drop. After the innermost tertiaries are moulted, the secondaries, starting from the innermost, begin to drop and this process continues until the outermost feathers are lost (centrifugal moult). In Southeast Europe, the first agrarian societies emerged around 7,000 BC, as evidenced by one of the earliest farming sites discovered in Vashtëmi, southeastern Albania, dating back to 6,500 BC. Anthropomorphic figurines were found in the Balkans around 6,000 BC, and in Central Europe by 5,800 BC. The Sesklo culture in Thessaly later expanded in the Balkans and gave rise to the Starčevo-K�r�s, Linearbandkeramik, and Vinča cultures. Neolithic traditions spread west and north to Northwestern Europe by around 4,500 BC through cultural diffusion and migration of peoples. The Vinča culture may have created an early form of writing, but it is not clear if these signs were truly developed writing or pictograms and ideograms.

Various explanations have been provided for Yale's representation in national elections since the end of the Vietnam War. Various sources highlight the spirit of campus activism that has existed at Yale since the 1960s, and the intellectual influence of Reverend William Sloane Coffin on many of the future candidates. Yale President Richard Levin attributes the run to Yale's focus on creating "a laboratory for future leaders," an institutional priority that began during the tenure of Yale Presidents Alfred Whitney Griswold and Kingman Brewster. Richard H. Brodhead, former dean of Yale College and now president of Duke University, stated: "We give very significant attention to orientation to the community in our admissions, and there is a very strong tradition of volunteerism at Yale." Yale historian Gaddis Smith notes "an ethos of organized activity" at Yale during the 20th century that led John Kerry to lead the Yale Political Union's Liberal Party, George Pataki the Conservative Party, and Joseph Lieberman to manage the Yale Daily News. In terms of major Canadian cities, St. John's has the highest fog frequency (124 days), windiest average speed (24.3 km/h or 15.1 mph), and cloudiest conditions (1,497 hours of sunshine). In contrast to other Canadian cities, St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season. Furthermore, it has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. However, precipitation is frequent and often heavy, occurring year-round. On average, summer is the driest season, with occasional thunderstorms. The wettest months are from October to January, with December being the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. This winter precipitation maximum is quite unusual for humid continental climates, which most commonly have a late spring or early summer precipitation maximum.

In Paris, the torch relay took place on April 7th, starting at the first level of the Eiffel Tower and concluding at the Stade Charléty. Initially planned to cover 28 kilometers, the route was shortened due to demands from Chinese officials. This came after protests from pro-Tibet and human rights activists sought to disrupt, hinder, or halt the procession. A planned ceremony at the city hall was cancelled upon the request of Chinese authorities, and the torch was transported by bus for the final leg instead of being carried by athletes. Prior to the relay's arrival in Paris, the city government had planned a peaceful protest to raise awareness about human rights issues. However, this event was also cancelled by the Chinese authorities.

According to surveys conducted in Europe and the United States, green is the most commonly associated color with nature, life, health, youth, spring, and hope. However, green also carries some contrary associations such as death, sickness, and the devil. In contrast, green is associated with positive symbols in China, representing fertility and happiness. Throughout history, green and red have been used to indicate social status, with green being worn by merchants, bankers, and the gentry, and red being the color of nobility. The Mona Lisa by Leonardo da Vinci, for example, portrays a non-noble character as green-clad, while the British House of Commons features green benches while the House of Lords uses red. Green is also associated with safety and permission, with a green light indicating go-ahead and a green card permitting permanent residency.

In the recent era, Libya made a comeback on the global stage. In 1999, the Libyan government secretly started negotiations with the British government to improve relations. In 2001, Gaddafi condemned the September 11 attacks on the U.S. by al-Qaeda, expressing empathy for the victims and calling for Libyan involvement in the War on Terror against militant Islamism. At the same time, the Libyan government continued to suppress domestic Islamism. Gaddafi also advocated for the wider implementation of sharia law. During this time, Libya strengthened its ties with China and North Korea, with Chinese President Jiang Zemin visiting in April 2002. The Libyan government was influenced by the Iraq War, as they renounced possession of weapons of mass destruction in December 2003, dismantling their chemical and nuclear weapons programs. As a result, relations with the U.S. improved, and UK Prime Minister Tony Blair met with Gaddafi in the Libyan desert in March 2004. Gaddafi traveled to the headquarters of the European Union (EU) in Brussels the following month, signaling improved relations.

Constantius ordered Liberius to go into exile in 356, giving him three days to comply. He was sent to Beroea in Thrace for banishment. Liberius was offered expensive presents if he accepted the Arian position but he refused. Constantius sent him 500 pieces of gold "to bear his charges" but Liberius refused them, saying he would give them to his flatterers. He also refused a similar present from the empress, telling the messenger to believe in Christ and not persecute the Church of God. Attempts were made to leave the presents in the Church, but Liberius threw them out. Constantius then sent for him under strict guard to Milan, where he courageously told Constantius that Athanasius had been acquitted at Sardica and his enemies were proven to be calumniators and impostors. He also stated that it was unjust.

The College Dropout, a highly anticipated album by Kanye West, was released by Roc-A-Fella in February 2004 and quickly climbed to the number two spot on the Billboard 200 chart, thanks to its popular debut single, "Through the Wire," which peaked at number fifteen on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. West's second single, "Slow Jamz," featuring Twista and Jamie Foxx, became an even bigger success, reaching the top spot for the three collaborators for the first time. The College Dropout received widespread critical acclaim from music critics, was voted the top album of the year by two major publications, and has consistently ranked among the greatest hip-hop works and debut albums by artists. One of the most notable songs on the album is "Jesus Walks," which explores the subject of faith and Christianity. Despite industry executives' predictions, the song managed to reach the top 20 of the Billboard pop charts.

On April 26, 1864, the Montana Territory was formed when the U.S. passed the Organic Act. Schools began to form in the area even before it was officially recognized as a territory, as families started to settle in the region. The initial schools were subscription schools, which were held in the teacher's home. The first formal school on record was at Fort Owen in the Bitterroot Valley in 1862, which had Indian children and children of Fort Owen employees as students. The first school term began in early winter and concluded on February 28. Mr. Robinson taught the classes. Another early subscription school was established by Thomas Dimsdale in Virginia City in 1863. This school charged students $1.75 per week. The Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly held its inaugural meeting in 1864. The first legislature authorized counties to levy taxes for schools, laying the groundwork for public education.

The last key aspect of identity formation is self-esteem. It refers to one's feelings and thoughts about their self-perception and identity. Most theories on self-esteem emphasize the universal desire to maintain, protect, and enhance it across all genders and age groups. Contrary to the common belief, there is no empirical evidence to support a significant drop in self-esteem during adolescence. While "barometric self-esteem" can fluctuate rapidly and cause significant distress and anxiety, the overall self-esteem remains stable throughout adolescence. The validity of global self-esteem scales has been questioned, and some argue that more specific scales may provide a better understanding of the adolescent experience. Girls are likely to have high self-esteem when they engage in supportive relationships with friends, as the most important aspect of friendship for them is having someone who can provide social and moral support.

The demographic history of Bermuda's population has been obscured over the past four centuries due to the ethnic homogenization that has occurred. Although there is no significant distinction between black and white Bermudians, there were once distinct groups with different ancestries. In the 17th century, white Protestants of English heritage were the majority, while there were also smaller minorities of Irish and Scots, who had been sent to Bermuda after their homelands were invaded by the English. Non-white minorities included Spanish-speaking free blacks from the West Indies, black chattel slaves captured from Spanish and Portuguese ships, and Native Americans from various tribes along the Atlantic seaboard. By the 19th century, the white ethnically-English Bermudians had lost their numerical advantage.

Intel had tried unsuccessfully to persuade Apple to switch the Macintosh platform to Intel chips. Apple believed that Intel's CISC architecture would not be able to compete against RISC processors. Although the Motorola 68040 offered the same features as the Intel 80486 and could perform significantly better on a clock-for-clock basis, the 486 had the ability to be clocked significantly faster without overheating problems, especially the clock-doubled i486DX2 which ran the CPU logic at twice the external bus speed, giving such equipped IBM compatible systems a significant performance advantage over their Macintosh equivalents. Apple's product design and engineering restricted the use of the '040 to their expensive Quadras for a time while the 486 was readily available to OEMs as well as enthusiasts who built their own machines.
